Award.AwardTitle: STEPS (Students Targeting Engineering and Physical Science)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project includes plans to increase the number of bachelor degrees in natural science and engineering at California State University Northridge (CSUN) by increasing retention rates of first-time freshmen and of transfer students. The goal is to develop a support network for success based on national and established campus best practices. Major components of the project are: 1) fostering success in lower-division mathematics, 2) a summer interdisciplinary team experience after the first year, and 3) career awareness activities.

Many of the additional degrees are expected to be earned by underrepresented students given that the institution is designated as Hispanic-serving. In addition, CSUN serves a region in which a majority of college-bound students are economically disadvantaged and are the first generation to pursue a college degree.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chief goal of the 5-year STEPS at CSUN grant was to increase the number of bachelor’s degrees awarded in engineering, mathematics and the physical sciences at California State University Northridge. We employed two main strategies: 1) fostering success in lower-division mathematics, particularly Calculus, and 2) SITE (Summer Interdisciplinary Team Experience), mini-research projects designed to increase retention in STEM majors for those who have completed Calculus. We assembled a database that included three baseline years of pre-STEP data (2008-2010) and five years of post-STEP data (2011-2015) in order to evaluate the impact of the grant strategies on number of degrees awarded.

Because the average time to graduation at CSUN in these majors is 6 to 7 years, we identified a benchmark reached before the midpoints of the majors that was a good indicator of likelihood to complete a STEP degree. Successful passage of Calculus is required in all STEP majors; and the majority of students complete this course early in the major, making this an excellent benchmark.

About 23% of the three pre-STEP cohorts (2008-2010) successfully completed Calculus at CSUN. Our strategy to improve pass rate in Calculus began on a limited basis on 2011 and was fully implemented in 2012. Pass rate increased to 24% for the 2011 cohort and to 30% for both the 2012 and 2013 cohorts, cohorts for which there has been sufficient time for students to complete the benchmark.

We expect that the increases in pass rate in Calculus will result in similar increases in degree completion. Only the three pre-STEP cohorts have had sufficient time to complete STEP degrees, and all three had nearly identical STEP-degree completion rates of 29%. Therefore, we expect a 30% rate for the 2011 cohort and 36% rate for the 2012 and subsequent cohorts. Figure 1 shows the effect of these increases on total STEP degrees earned above the pre-STEP 29% completion rate. We project that a total of 196 additional STEP degrees will be awarded as a result of the strategies of STEPS at CSUN for cohorts 2011-2015. Because the strategies that produced these increases are institutionalized, the 7% point increase in degrees awarded should continue to impact future cohorts.

The 3-week SITE summer research experience was implemented 6 times (2011-2016) including 23 projects and 230 student participants (46% URM and 23% women), the majority having just completed their sophomore level course work. Responses to exit questionnaires indicate that students highly valued the experience, which increased or maintained their interest in completing their STEM major, their academic-skill levels, and their interest in pursuing faculty research and/or industry internships. For most questions URM students had comparable responses to those of the whole group but were slightly higher on two aspects:  the increase in their commitment to complete a STEM major (82% compared to 78%) and on how SITE gave them a better understanding of how they will use their STEM skills and knowledge in their future careers (81% compared to 77%).  Male and female students also had similar responses on most questions, except for the following: 1) 83% of women compared to 74% of men stated that SITE gave them better understanding of how they will use their STEM skills and knowledge in their future careers, 2) 74% of women compared to 70% of men reported that participating in SITE increased confidence in their academic skills, and 3) 89% of men compared to 83% of women found that the team project made them more positive toward working in groups. In follow-up interviews, students highlighted the value of working with faculty on projects with real applications, applying material learned in courses to solving complex problems, and the opportunity to think about careers in industry. At this early stage in their educational careers, SITE represented the first time that these students were able to engage in and reflect upon these important aspects of STEM training. Overall the student reports indicate that SITE led to a major commitment to their STEM careers and in particular among URM and female students who have been shown to be receptive to programs offering research experiences.
